Ginza is high end shopping destination and the large department stores like Mitsukoshi have wonderful food halls where you can buy all types of food. Tshujiki fish market is a 10min walk away and everyone should go here before they close and relocate it next year. The hotel staff were most helpful and tourist information sheets are available in English from the concierge. The Narita Limosuine Bus drops off and picks off from the hotel front door so again this takes any stress away from travellers visiting Japan for the first time.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I have stayed at this location for at least 30 nights in the last year and I can tell you without a doubt that for the money you will not find a better value in Tokyo for the money - especially in the Ginza area.The staff is amazing - the bus from the airport has direct drop-off and pick up - and the location is amazing - only a few blocks from one of the most amazig areas in the world - Ginza. It is also central to Tokyo station and many of the key subway / train lines in Tokyo like the Ginza / Hinya lines.The rooms are small - but so are most rooms in Tokyo (per western standards) - but they are amazingly clean and always perfect - something I value from travelling around the world. The rooms on the premium level are amazing - but even the rooms on the regular levels are great- the showers are perfect, the rooms are super clean, and the staff are just perfect - exactly what you want after flying all night to get to Tokyo. The bar on the first floor has good food and great drinks for the price - something you will learn is rare in Tokyo - one of the most expensive cities in the world.I stay here everyt time I come to Tokyo (which is aabout every six weeks) for a reason - I save my company money and the location simply can't be beat -both from a business and from a tourist perpesctive.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I usually stay here when I travel on business and it's always a comfortable stay. The location is convenient in that it's walking distance to the subway, so you can get anywhere relatively quickly. There are lots of eating options, from food courts to fancy restaurants, and the Ginza district has a lot of shops, if you like shopping. Most of the shopping is high-end, but you can walk a bit further and find options in different price ranges. There's a ramen shop across the street that's cheap and tasty.This hotel does have a govt rate, if that's something for which you qualify. The restaurant Fiore has a lot of good choices for breakfast, and when you check in you can ask for a coupon for a discount on breakfast. At 1500 yen, it's not bad, and you can have a full breakfast buffet with both western and Japanese options. The rooms are pretty standard for Japan - small, but not the smallest I've seen. It's starting to look a bit worn if you look closely, but it was comfortable enough. The Airport Limosuine bus has pickups and dropoffs from the front of the hotel, which made it convenient to leave - you just get on the bus and it drops you off at Narita or Haneda.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Courtyard by Marriott is a centrally located hotel in Ginza Area. It is  a few steps away from the convenient stores, family mart , Lawson and Sunkus where you can buy your basic amenities , toiletries and water...  the hotel does not provide free bottled water ...  Maybe because   water in the hotel is potable anyway.Shops are just few steps away. The biggest Uniglo store is a block away as well  Forever 21, H&M ans Zara shops. you can change  money from the reception , conversion rate is almost the same , they don't charge commission. The train station , Ginza station is just few minutes by foot .Excellent Service- it s like home... Given the innate Japanese characteristic of being courteous and  mild mannered . Their service is incomparable. from the moment that we checked in we felt  that we were indeed  welcome in the hotel, the concierge will help you with  luggage but they don't accept tip.  It was raining and they provided umbrella for al the guests ... I needed some personal amenity and they bought it for me and delivered to my room. There is nothing they can not to help their guests   Our stay  was truly hassle free. It's like you are home and you can count on them for things that you need.They have the 2 Marriot  signature pillow , with japanese  robe, slippers toiletries , new and soft towel. I accidentally came across the housekeeping  staff while cleaning  the room and they really wash all sections of the room and the bathroom thoroughly . They wash  the cups and glass by hot water first before finally rinsing & dry them..Thumbs  up and salute to CY  our Concierge for all the help she extended to us during our stay, We will definitely recommend your hotel to our clients & friends...And . Yes, we will be back !

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We only had one night inTokyo. This was perfect as we hopped on a bus at the airport and took it to the city airport and then grabbed a taxi to this hotel in Ginza for about $5. To go back to the airport the next day we took the airport bus right from our hotel lobby. It was so convenient. The hotel is a bit tired but I would stay there again for the convenience. We checked in late afternoon on a Monday and spent a great night in Ginza. The next morning we woke up, met our guide in the lobby and spent the morning and early afternoon touring Tokyo. It was so easy as our guide brought us back to the hotel and half an hour later we were on the bus to the airport with time to spare. We bought the bus tickets at the hotel so they were expecting us. It was perfect!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Rooms are clean as expected. Biggest issue is internet access. Room only has wired ethernet, and network isn't fast when up, but often didn't connect at all. Wireless in the hotel lobby common area wasn't any better with inconsistent connectivity. Over a 4 day stay, fortunately issues were on the last 2 days where work was mostly done; but still concerning.Conveniently located a couple of blocks from the Ginza main boulevard with many shops and food choices.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: What others say is true - good location, hotel is clean and what you expect in a courtyard. For the business traveller though, be warned the Internet access is patchy - ok when it is on, but was not available at important times twice in the 6 days I stayed there.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Hotel is beautiful. Staffs are friendly. great value for money. Rooms/bathrooms are very clean.This hotel is located at a very convenient location. So many bakeries around. All the high end brand stores close by. subway is close by. You have Turkish and Indian Delight at walking distance.Highly recommended hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We just returned from a skiing trip to Japan. We spent the last three nights at Courtyard by Marriott and it was fabulous!The staff were fabulous and the gentleman (whose name I have forgotten) at Concierge was delightful!The rooms were impeccably clean and a good size...we travelled with two teenage children who had their own room and we felt secure when we downstairs in the lobby.Breakfast was good value and the location is brilliant! We were able to walk or catch a cheap taxi to nearly everything we wanted to go too (Bird Land restaurant and the Ninja restaurant to name a few!)We were sad to leave...highly recommended!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel is a little gem in very expensive Tokyo. In Ginza and close to many restaurants and the shopping district you can choose from several subway lines. Not easy to get to the airport however if you have too many or heavy bags. Take a taxi to the main station- about 15 dollars and then the train to narita if you want to save usd 300 one way to the airport.Breakfast is expensive but there are several starbucks close by. If you are Marriott rewards member there are several little perks like free food and drinks coupons. The staff were friendly at the restuarant but not the warmest welcome at the reception which is unusual in Japan where everyone is really polite. The rooms are a good size and the bed is very comfy with a good size bathroom. When we left the concierge was really quick finding us a cab and putting our luggage inside. Something you;d be hard pressed to get at a NYC hotel even with a big tip.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA
user_name:
spicelore
New York City, New York, USA

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel was way better than I had anticipated...the name "Courtyard" throws you off. As with other reviewers, I did find the rooms and beds to be on the small side, but that is the only downside to this hotel. My adult daughter accompanied me on this trip and we were able to find a spot in the room to set aside our luggage and unpack all our things. The bathroom has lots of extra free toiletries than most hotels and the toilet has a bidet. The heat/air conditioning worked very well and was very quiet The t.v. could have had more English channels as there wasn't much to choose from. The food is really good, the rooms are clean and quiet but most of all, the service is impeccable! This was my first trip to Japan, and I was absolutely astonished at how polite and accommodating the Japanese people are! There is high speed WiFi in all the rooms which is free if you're a Marriott Rewards members. This hotel is very close to the Ginza shopping district, which is like 5th Avenue in New York City.FYI - the best way to get from Narita to this hotel is with the Bus Limousine that you will see a big counter for at the airport after you retrieve your luggage. It's about $35, which beats a taxi ($500) and if you're hauling a lot of luggage, the train.Lastly, even though most Marriotts have a contract with Pepsi, this one did have Coke Zero in the room fridge, which made me very happy!If I have the opportunity to return to Tokyo, I will definitely stay here again!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel offers excellent service but was quite expensive for a solo traveler on vacation, although I don't know how the cost compares to other Tokyo hotels. The location is very convenient to the subway. (From Higashi-ginza Station #H9/A11, take exit gate A1 to the street, do a U-turn on the sidewalk, then turn right at the corner and go 2 blocks. Total walk is less than 5 minutes.) The hotel has a high-end feel as compared to hotels in the US. The room was quite small, almost cramped, but I didn't spend much time there anyway. The immediate area doesn't offer much for tourists except high-end shopping - think Cartier and Gucci - and the fish market. I had trouble connecting to the in-room WiFi, but the wired connection worked fine. (In-room internet is free to Marriott Rewards members, otherwise 1300 yen per 24 hours.) The room was immaculate and the staff extremely courteous and efficient.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: GOOD CHOICE!!! Japan can be a bit "antiseptic" (although well meaning) but English speakers will warm to the hospitality of this venue. Tokyo and especially area known as GINZA is very expensive, so this Marriott property is a real value. Better than any US Courtyard product but NO frills here so all of the Marriott Gold/Platinum perks are NOT available -- so manage your expectations regarding swilling drinks and food in the lounge---cause there isn't one. If you want JW Marriott it will cost you 3X as much! Staff is EXCEPTIONAL and very capable. If you have ANY issues during your stay they will resolve them quickly. Use the 3000YEN (ie: $36) "Limousine Bus" from Narita DIRECTLY to the hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This is a nice hotel in a good location however one word of warning is that which perfectly formed the rooms are very small, I would suggest that you avoid if you have more than hand luggage. Also be sure to do some excercise and limbering up before the shower if you are tall to avoid that you are unable to get under the shower head; restaurant is fine for breakfast even though the sausages are hot dogs!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Wonderful front desk staff who were extremely helpful and greeted us by name when we arrived or left the hotel. Hotel is in a great location within walking distance to the subway, many restaurant options and shopping. The only downside is the size of the rooms. They are very small and with two suitcases we hardly had room to walk around. If you are traveling with any more than two adults I would recommend getting a 2nd adjoining room.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Hotel was perfect! very clean and pleasant staff. free wifi in the lobby and coffee in the morning. Location was perfect in the heart of Ginza. Lots to see and do around the hotel. Walkable to the fish market. Close to the metro station. Lots of shops and restaurants. Walkable to imperial palace. Room was good size and modern. Would highly recommend.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stay at this hotel when on business in Tokyo. It's located in one of the higher end areas of Tokyo, but is fairly priced. First the downsides, as this is a Courtyard there is no lounge for Platinum members but they do provide you with a couple of drink coupons upon check in. There is also no breakfast included, but they provide a coupon for a discount at the onsite restaurant. Now for the positives; the rooms are clean with comfortable beds and wifi in each room. The bathrooms are modern and clean and include toilets with heated seats. There is also a nice tea room restaurant in the lobby area of the hotel that is nice for business meetings. One of the main reasons I stay here is the convenience getting to and from Narita airport. The hotel is located just a few minutes away by taxi from Tokyo central station. There is also a convenient airport bus that costs roughly 35 USD one way that picks up directly in front of the hotel. There are no additional stops and the bus goes direct to Narita taking about an hour. For this convenience, the reasonably priced rooms, great location, good service, and comfortable beds, I recommend this hotel if you are in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed here twice this year on mixed business-leisure trips. The beds are superbly comfortable, probably thanks to being on the stiffer side providing the necessary back support (unlike most hotels in the USA that almost invariably cause back pain). Service is good and efficient. Breakfast buffet is quite good with a tilt towards western food. Location in Ginza is superb for shopping and connection to the transportation grid. Hotel has good shuttle bus to the airport. My only complaint is that WiFi is sub-par with problems both times I stayed there, something that should not happen in a modern hotel in the year 2012. I should note that surprisingly this seems a general problem in Japan. Overall very good value.
user_name:
Jojo M
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I've stayed 7 days in this hotel so far. Rooms are modern and comfortable, well maintained. The location is great: 3 blocks from Higashi-Ginza subway, around the corner from the Ginza shopping district, but not as noisy. My only gripe is the smoking: the hotel has a "japanese businessmen bar" on the lower level where smoking is de rigueur; that smoke gets all over the lobby and can make you gag. Also, there seems to be smoke on the guest room hallways (so far I've noticed it on floors 10 and 6). The management should do something for the non-smoking patrons that DO NOT want to inhale second-hand smoke. Restaurant in the lobby is OK.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Hotels in Tokyo are expensive, so the Courtyard Ginza provided a value proposition with all the benefits of a modern 4 star hotel with famous Japanese hospitality. Location great - close to Tokyo central station, Tsukiji fish market, Japan's flagship Uniqlo store & a host of great restaurants nearby. The hotel is nice, super clean and cosy (but then everything is clean & space is a premium in Japan). But within limited space this hotel manages to provide comfortable living area. The rooms are well appointed, with all amenities. The bathroom is small, but has great toilets (as a foreigner this is something I will talk about for a long time to come!). Not standard Marriott beds but comfortable enough. Great breakfast & coffee places round the corner, convenience store just a few steps away.The tube station is Higoshi Ginza & within walking distance - so rest of Tokyo is well connected.In the lobby you'll find printed takeaways with helpful tips on where to visit, which tube station to go to etc. I thought that was very thoughtful. Would definitely recommend this hotel

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed at the Mrriott Ginza hotel a couple of weeks ago. This is an OK hotel from all perspectives. Check-in very professional, breakfast staff very professional and room is very nice and clean.The only thing that puzzled me was the TV. I'm not the most technical of people, but I did not manage to get anything but Japanese programs

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Imagine our shock when we entered the Courtyard by Marriott in Ginza, thinking it was another 2.5-3 star group tour hangout, like the one in our home city. This is a 4 star, clean, beautifully appointed hotel in one of Tokyo's best locations. it's a 10 minute walk to Tsukiji Market, a 10 minute walk to the subway system and a 10-15 minute walk to the centre of the Ginza shopping area. When the Kabuki Theatre re-opens in the Spring of 2013, you can walk there in about 10 minutes too. The hotel staff are very friendly and customer service-oriented. When we checked out, they actually said 'thank you', which is more than some 5 star hotels offer, The hallways are comfortable to walk through, the rooms are very nicely decorated. The beds are super comfortable. The business centre offers free internet and there is a fitness centre--which is also free. The only downside is that the breakfast was not the best we had ever had, but it was OK. There are two convenience stores within a 3 minute walk. All-in-all, and I have stayed at a few 4-5 star properties in Tokyo over the years, this is a great place to stay and I will now make this my first choice on future visits to Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: There are far nicer properties to stay at in Tokyo, for a price. This Courtyard is located in Ginza and high dollar shopping and the subway system are just out the front door. The rooms are nice enough, but be prepared to part with at least $250 for a night. The staff were extraordinarily friendly. As noted by other reviewers, the bed here was nice and soft - something that's proving quite difficult to find in other Japanese hotels. The room was of a decent size and well appointed with a massive television. No real workspace to speak of if you're here on business.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Location was perfect. Lots of cheap eating houses as well as more upmarket ones withing a block or two. Airport Limousine Bus stops right outside and within easy walking distance of 3 metro stations. Free wi fi and good business centre with computers/printers for guests. The rooms were comfortable if not overly large but good size for Japan.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Location really could not have been better, great location for central Ginza. Free WIFI in the room was appreciated. Did eat in the bar area, solidly good food, reasonable prices...wine and french fries were fantastic. Bed was comfortable, which isn't always easy to find in Japan if you like soft beds. Room was on the interior of the bldg and below the skyline, so it was a bit like being in a cruise ship interior with the fake windows...not a big deal, just keep the drapes closed. I ate breakfast on the last day there, it was excellent, both local and western style items to choose from...a nice treat!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: It is in the centre of Ginza,10 minute walk to Ginza subway station and to Tsukiji Fish Market, You can also reach Shinjuku 新宿 in 10 min by subway. Room size is about the same size as American size Marriott hotel room with a hot water pot to make tea and coffee. There is a 24 hr gym. Wifi internet is free for Marriott Rewards programme member, otherwise there is a nominal fee. Staff is very helpful to provide maps and directions to attractions. There are several restaurants in the hotel and there is a 10% discount breakfast coupon available for guests I was booked this hotel by the popular JTB Sunrise Tour in Japan and hence tour buses of Sunrise Tours pick up travellers there.There is also a convenient store within 100 ft from the hotel

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel couldn't have been more conveniently located. The airport limousine bus stops right in front of it so it was very convenient and easy to get to from the airport which was great for me as a first time visitor to Tokyo. The subway station was close and so was everything else in Ginza. Pricey for a Courtyard but compared to the prices of 5 star hotels in Tokyo this was a deal. The rooms are small but for one person they suited me just fine. Everything was spotless and modern. I had breakfast one day and it was pretty decent. It was pretty much everything i expected from a Courtyard, clean, functional, and modern.The only thing I didn't like was the bed. Part of the reason for booking a Marriott was because I didn't want to end up with a hard Japanese bed and that's exactly what I got. Being that Marriott is an American chain that is known for having soft plush beds, they should have the same beds worldwide.I also wish they had a dedicated concierge. I asked the front desk some questions and they didn't really know what I was talking about.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel is at the center of key attractions, Ginza shopping center, Tsukiji Fish Market, and Sushi Dai. It is also a few blocks away from the the metro. The hotel room (at least the one we were in) are "U.S. size" Courtyard room, so no complain there. The rooms are a bit dated and of course no lounge for a Category 6 hotel. As a Platinum with Marriott, I was not upgraded and the arrival gift is mediocre.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: A bit pricey but it is in the high rent district of Ginza so no complaints. Easy to find after taking train / subway from Haneda airport late at night. Nice quiet comfortable room. Staff speak English well and are very helpful.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Good location that is easy walking to the Ginza. I was there for business. Basic amenities at the hotel but they are all there. Buffet for breakfast and dinner is ok, nothing special, however does cover a wide variety of travels choices which is always difficult for hotels.Room is a little small by North American standards. Had to step out of bathroom to towel dry after a shower. Other than that staff is super friendly and helpful so make up for the shortcomings. I may stay again next trip to Tokyo but will also check what else is around the area.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We had read that the rooms here were small. Singles might be, but our double was not. It was modern, very clean, and the most well lit room we've ever stayed in. Breakfast was very expensive and nothing special. No big deal. Short walk to Ginza and to subway/trains. Would stay no place else when we return to Tokyo. Extremely clean city. Why aren't our cities this clean? It's embarrassing to me.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We had a family holiday in Tokyo staying at Courtyard Hotel Marriott. Fantastic, big room, excellent breakfast & meals all reasonably priced and the staff so helpful in arranging tours, taxis, airport bus and where to go with plenty of guides and helpful hints of what to do. The hotel is easy walking distance to the main shopping areas, train etc. Best shops were Takashimaya Nihonbashi and Printemps for prices and such excellent service and Bic Camera for all electrical and electronic items.One tip when traveling in a taxi have the Google Map ready in Japanese.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Very pleased with this property. 10th floor room was very quiet and clean. Room was a bit small by US standards but more than adequate for my business needs. Lots of shopping and food choices nearby... From $ to $$$$. Room was a bit expensive but probably due to the fact it's in Ginza shopping district.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Booked this Hotel for our first night in Tokyo with Family. While I have often visited here on business this was my first visit with my children and we found it very difficult to locate a hotel that would allow us to accommodate 4 of us in the one room for a reasonable price. After much searching we located the Marriott and booked a family room for 4 persons. On arrival we were shown to our twin room which had two single beds only! Our complaint was met with no help whatsoever except the offer of a second room at the corresponding twice the original cost! Staff were incredibly intransigent. Production of the original booking clearly indicative we had booked a family room was no help. Apparently a family room means they allow you to have 4 people in the room but do not need to provide beds- incredible! This hotel is well located and I have no complaints other then the above so if you are not travelling with Children then you should be fine.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Location is good as you are at the bottom of the shopping district.Nondescript from the outside and apart form the jazzy lobby it is nondescript on the inside as well.Small basic rooms with not much in them but very good individual room based wifi.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We stayed here again in September, and once again the hotel proved to be ideal for our purposes. It is not an upmarket establishment, but it is clean, newly and well-decorated and within the context of hotels in Japan, (small), it is fine for a short break because it is well located for shopping in Ginza and close to nearby restaurants. It is also on the bus route from Narita and Haneda, which is quite important. Never used the dining or other facilties, but they were not included in my expectations.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This is not the hotel that you will remember years after you have been to Tokyo. Rooms are very small, bathroom is in sort of brown plastic and breakfast is average. But yes, it's very well located close to the shopping street, fish market and in centre of town. Also price is ok for Tokyo. Service was good and rooms were clean. I would have just gone for the little extra for once you are in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel is perfect for people who want to go to Tsukiji fish Market. Its about a ten minute walk away - so makes the 4.30'ish start more bearable. Other than that Ginza is central and easy to get to all the other districts. Its also really great value. The service was brilliant. Get on to the Marriott club programme and get free internet. The restaurant is ok - mainly for business customers.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Contemporary style hotel in a good location - central to Ginza district for shopping, and between 2 subway stations.The wifi didn't work in the room so used the cable. Breakfast was expensive and not a lot of choice- but there is a Denny's across the road and coffee shops close by if you want to breakfast outside the hotel. Our hotel room faced a side street, so not much of a view, but it was quiet.Shower had to be used carefully as the design of the bath sends all the water onto the bathroom floor. I had to use all the towels to mop up a flood the first time I turned it on!Airport limousine bus was very convenient when we returned to the airport. Only here 2 nights so not much time to get a feel for the place.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The location of this hotel is very convenient for shopping, dining out and also if you are taking the airport limousine bus. It is also close to metro stations. The standard room is not big but recently refurbished and its clean.However what I really appreciated was the customer service- before arriving they were very good with queries I sent them online and took the trouble to call a shop for me and also suggested alternatives.As we flew in to Tokyo on an overnight flight and arrived really early in the morning, we were very appreciative of the fact that the front desk staff checked us into the room straightaway at past 7am in the morning without any additional charge. Would recommend as a business hotel for Ginza area.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stayed only one night at this hotel since I had a 17 hour layover in Tokyo. First, the staff is really friendly. Great service. Breakfast buffet is great. Internet speed is awesome. Room is very clean. You would think that you're staying in a full service Marriott. Great location too! I would recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Good location and friendly staff. Rooms are larger than average, were clean and comfortable. The hotel is located in the heart of the shopping district and there are many good choices for restuarants nearby.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stayed at this hotel for one nght, and this was exactly what it promised to be. It is a fairly no frills hotel as you'd expect of a courtyard marriott if you're American. However, the service, cleanliness, and efficiency of the reservation staff was amazing. Maho Oguchi deserves to be mentioned by name, as he not only gave me loads of travel information for a jetlagged single business traveller to take the cheapest/fastest way to the hotel from the airport, but also making my reservation, cancelling it, and remaking it again with perfect customer service. I never ate in the hotel (it didn't look that great and seemed overpriced) but I went to the Mitsukoshi dept store which is literally a 5 minute walk to their food hall and brought stuff back. The hotel room itself was standard size for America, but large and spacious for Ginza/Tokyo. It had a standard minifridge. The toiletries were nothing special, but they were (I think?) better than Courtyard's usual stuff. The two Japanese style robes were a nice touch. Basically the nice parts of the hotel is the excellent location, the size and cleanliness of the rooms, and the reservation staff that make it easy to plan the stay from abroad. The room itself is "eh" and the bathroom is just the standard courtyard shower with plastic.
user_name:
AmericaninJkta29
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The staff could not have been more friendly and helpful and everything from leaving our bags for a few days whilst we visited Kyoto to arranging the Narita airport bus worked like clockwork. However, there is a price to pay for this great service with high prices for in-room dining (very simple and limited choice) and basic drinks at the bar but there again you're sitting in the middle of Ginza so don't be too surprised. Oh, one more thing...why is it that a brand like the Marriott can't teach its staff to make a basic Caesar Salad?

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Amongest most American hotel chain, Ginza Courtyard was surprisingly the cheapest (as a corporate traveler using the chain is a must) Well, what a terrible mistake that I made. Service was the worst, sure they are located in Ginza, most expensive 5th avenue-like district in Tokyo, but hate the fact that the workers discliminate guests by nationality. This is non-smoking hotel, yet I've seen Europeans smoking in the hallway, no one bother them. Yet, I came back from jog and they asked for my hotel key, claiming I might not be a guest (I'm an Asian, by the way) I was talking to other guests from SE Asia, and he told me he was asked the same. Jeez! Marriott discliminates by race now!? They also failed to take a note of my Marriott #, hence I had to come home, weeks later file missing points request. This hotel is going down soon, maybe that's why they are so cheap, waiting to close down. Anyways I have directed my comapny of 1000 employees to blacklist this location.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The hotel is very well located at Ginza district close to the metro station. It is very expensive... breakfast is not included. Because of the price, I think of a few downsides: wifi works only at the reception. Bedrooms are too small. There is only 1 channel in English.
user_name:
VinhasL
Sao Jose Dos Campos, SP

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed here for a 2 night stopover in Tokyo, rooms small but clean & comfortable. Breakfast was good & staff very friendly & speak good English. Location great close to shopping and many fine restaurants. Room supplies kimono's, shower gels & caps, razors etc. Some English TV channels & Wifi availbale in room for a small cost.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed here for a change when travelling back through Tokyo to the UK on business. Chose hotel due to Marriott gold elite perks. Took limousine bus from Haneda airport with no probs, bus stops right outside. Staff very friendly check in was no problem. Room keys have the nifty feature of choosing the elevator floor number automatically, never seen that before. Stayed on 9 th floor, seemed reasonably quiet. There is a definate smell on this floor, could not work out what, even tho smoke free smelt like stale tobacco. Room fine, usual Tokyo size, fixtures and fittings again absolutely fine. Kettle supplied but absolutely min of beverages, ie two sachets ofbgreed tea powder, two fingers of coffee, and that was it. No complimentary water, although water in mini bar which may or may not have been free. Turns out no exec lounge in hotel, but got free internet ok, courtesy of club card. However, voucher for one free happy hour drink (5 to 8pm) and a reduction in breakfast price by 5 pounds to 18 pounds not really good enough to replace free breakfast. Went into dinner buffet, and walked out again, very poor, most of the food not labelled and unimaginative. Moved to japanese restaurant downstairs and again poorly set out english menus so had a much better cheaper meal in Ginza. Given this is a hotel full of english speaking guests the layout of menus, posters and food labelling really is poor. Somebody needs to stop and just look at what a hungry guest sees who doesnt read Japanese. Many western guests are nervous about trying Japanese food, the hotel COULD be a great introduction. Hotel location right in centre of Ginza so very good. Caught coach for Narita with no problems, staff very helpful, it stops right outside the hotel. Check out was easy and painless.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I don't think it is possible to fall over in the room without hitting a wall. However, the location is great for exploring. Within walking distance to Ginza shopping, train to anywhere, and lots of great food. They provide you with a Kimono for practicing karate in your room.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We stayed here for 2 nights with Marriott points and enjoyed our experience very much. The room was comfortable and clean, the staff was attentive and helpful, and the location was convenient. The hotel is a short walk (5, maybe 10 minutes) from several subway stations, only 2 blocks over from the main street in Ginza, and a 15 minute walk to Tsukiji Fish Market (we enjoyed breakfast in the outer market there).There was free wifi in the lobby. There were also free maps and information about the attractions in Tokyo in English.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Great location and confortable stay. Rooms are small but well appointed, great amenities. Delivered the quality and service expected. My only wish is for a business lounge.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Make no mistake about it, by "reasonable" rates we mean "compared to others in Tokyo", because it still costs a little over $300 a night! But it's well worth it!First, the hotel is located in the heart of Ginza, where real estate is probably the most expensive on Earth. It's like you stay in a hotel on New York's Fifth Avenue, where designer, expensive and elegant boutiques are located. The hotel is actually on Showa dori, one block away from Higashi-Ginza subway station, from where you can easily go anywhere else in Tokyo within one of the most elaborated subway networks in the world.The hotel is clean and modern. Our room is as large as a Courtyard Marriott's room in the US (but this Courtyard Marriott Tokyo Ginza is more on a par with J W Marriott in the US in terms of status and rates, as there is no J W Marriott in Tokyo). There is wired internet in the room for a small fee and wi-fi in the lobby area. Breakfast is not included in the rates, but we do not recommend having breakfast or dinner in the hotel's restaurants, for you can get much better food at much better prices outside, anywhere around. Coffee can only be found in the lobby or in the restaurant, but not in the room. And by the way, Denny's is across the street!What we liked at this hotel is not just the convenience of its location, the excellent service from its staff, but also little things like a counter in the lobby providing sheets with clear and useful guidances for attractions for tourists, or like their toilets! Although the staff is not particularly fluent in English, but you can feel that they go out their way to make you happy and, boy, they are really nice and courteous. On our next trip to Tokyo, we will definitely stay at this hotel again.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We go to Japan once or twice a year for fun. We don't speak Japanese at all although we can read some of the signs so a lot of forward planning ahead but after all these years it is not difficult for me anymore but I want to put this in perspective for anyone who might not read any characters and is in Japan for the first time.Couryard by Marriott is in a really convenient spot it's 2 blocks or 5 minutes behind the main Ginza shopping street with the big department stores and flagship stores. It is 1 block from one subway line and 2 blocks or so from the other subway line or JR line which will link you to all the other popular touristy areas and beyond.It is also within walking distance to the Tsukiji fish market which if you want to go and get a ticket to see the tuna auction at 4am, will prove very useful as you don't have far to go.The hotel is at the end stop for the airport limousine from Narita so you can just hop on and forget about changing trains and carting your luggage around. For someone who does not speak Japanese this is helpful although I've also done it the other way which isn't too hard but needs more concentration.The rooms are big for Japan business hotels, honestly! Their reception staff speaks really really good english - this is invaluable and rather unusual for Japan. They have free wi-fi in the lobby which works well.Forget the breakfast in the hotel unless you have an inclusive package. Forget the Dennys across the road too. Go to these nice Japanese coffee chains that does good coffee and breakfast package. Outside the front door turn left and after a few doors you see Rullys coffee. Continue further and across the road/traffic lights is Pronto. Go out the back door to the lane behind the hotel it's Doutor coffee which is my personal favourite. You might need to point and wave around but ALL Japanese staff are incredibly helpful so you're bound to muddle through.If you fancy noodles or other foods, and if you're on holiday and get up late anyway, go for an early lunch at a restaurant most open by 11am. All the big department stores like Matsuya, Matsuzakaya, GInza, Mitsukoshi all have little restaurants on the top floors you can choose your food by these plastic displays outside first then just point to the staff what you want. Or if you want to buy your own Bento box or snacks, go to the basement floors of the department stores at about the same time and you can eat to your hearts content.In summary, now that i've found this hotel I'll be going back there again for my next trip because it's so convenient and comfortable, and it's more or less the same price as other hotels of the same class.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Perfect place for great price. Stayed here for budget, casual trips, and at Peninsula for higher end accomodations. Courtyard is clean, nice, new in appearance, great breakfast, and perfect location. We found it funny to see a Denny's across the street.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The hotel is close to the subway stop, and very convenient to all the stores and shops of Ginza. You can walk to the JR station as well, it is about 15-20 minutes. Very comfortable rooms, but no heated toilet seats in the bathrooms? The English language skills of the front desk staff were only average, we had a very hard time communicating. But they were very helpful and friendly, and even arranged free tickets to a Japanese theater for us. Very little English TV offerings, BBC channel mostly. Would have liked to have CNN or ESPN. Staff was exceptionally helpful with our requests. They also have a bus that you can take direct to Narita from the hotel. Overall I am glad we stayed at the Courtyard Ginza, but it could have been better.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel is within walking distance of the tokyo subway. The airport bus from Narita also stops right outside. A number of restaurants, fast food and mini market nearby. We had a great dinner at Watame, a few streets away. There is a 12 storey Uniqlo outlet within walking distance.The standard room is on the small side but it is modern. This is the only Japanese hotel (outside the 5 star range) I have stayed in which provides English TV channels.The conceirge provides info leaflets on how to get to various attractions from the hotel which is really useful.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Very welcoming staff who are always willing to help and advise and speak great english.. Serverd directly by the Limosine Bus service from Narita.Rooms very clean but as a business person with evenings on my own, TV is limited to BBC World and the odd other english channels, so remember to load up your iphone with movies & tv.Menu in restaurant is very limited for evening meals so I would suggest eating out be the meal of choice. Breakfast is also very expensive if you eat (continental type breakfast) in the restraurant, would suggest that the lounge be a better value for money option.Taxis readily available and very professional.Yen to GBP makes Japan very expensive and is not reflective on the charges for this hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This entire hotel is spotless. The staff are wonderfully helpful - we were constantly at the front desk with questions about directions, opening hours, the train to Kyoto, etc. They all speak excellent English.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: First checked in, got my room and was blown away by how incredible the room was: huge, for a major city, filled with amenities like a massage chair, extra large bathroom, on and on. Couldn't figure out how this wasn't a top rated Tokyo hotel. Decided to stay on and was told I would have to move to a regular room. It became clear. The 2nd room was fine, but just a standard hotel room. Nice, as all Marriott rooms are, but nothing special, unlike the first night. So my recommendation is: try for a free upgrade to the top floor or pay the difference. It really was an exceptional room in a fun part of tokyo

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Great location to major subway lines and of course Ginza. Rooms are spacious for Asia, clean, and with soft beds. Only downfall is that WiFi is only available in the lobby. You can connect to the internet in rooms but only by LAN.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel is in the Ginza District, close to many stores and restaurants, as well as underground train stations. The Tsukiji Fish Market is within walking distance. The staff was very courteous and helpful. We ate at the breakfast buffet on a few occasions and the food selection was very good. The room was larger than anticipated, and the bed was very comfortable. We would definitely stay at this hotel in the future.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Many reasons that this is one of the better value choices in Tokyo. One of the standard airport buses goes directly to the Marriott Courtyard from Narita, which is a huge point as the airport is so far away and the city is massive so getting from point to point isn’t easy. The rooms are large by local standard and you’re within a few minutes’ walk of all the shopping you could possible desire. The staff is friendly, very helpful and many speak several languages. It’s fairly easy to get a taxi right our front and all the taxi drivers know where the hotel is, which is another big plus if you don’t speak Japanese. My only negative was that, it’s not possible to get a Japanese meal past 9:00pm. Although there are two restaurants in the basement floor, neither seats people nor serves after 9. Really odd in a 24 a day place like Tokyo. I had to settle for some very mundane western fare from the ground floor restaurant because I was too tired after arrival to venture out. All in all a great place and the price is very competitive.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Room was very small though almost all hotel rooms in Tokyo are small. The hotel is close to Higashi-Ginza Subway station and easy to go to Haneda Airport.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: After reading all the reviews on this hotel, I decided it was a good place for my son and I to stay. While the rooms are small, this is typical of most Asian hotels. The room was very clean and the service my housekeeping was great. The hotel has a few good restaurants in it and a beer/wine bar (which on check in we got a coupon for a glass of wineor beer each evening complimentary). We had the breakfast buffett 1 morning (they give you a 10% discount coupon when you register) the food was outstanding. For dinner and lunches we tried to eat inmore traditional locations. Though there is a Denny's accross the street, we had breakfast there the morning after we arrived. It was a good breakfast as well. The other nice thing about the hotel, it's only about a 5 minute walk from the Ginsu subway stop, making it convienent when taking the train from the airport to the city.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Be prepared the rooms are small which is standard for Japan and the hotel doesn't always recognize Marriott Platinum status until pointed out but its sooo close to some of the key attractions that it is easy to overlook these minor issues.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Final night in Japan is a luxury at the Courtyard. After working a week at Yokosuka Naval Base, this is a treat. Staff is true Japanese (very courteous, helpful). They upgraded my room to 11th floor (request if you can). Everything is spotless for a great value AAA rate. You can walk three blocks to the best nighttime light show in the world: the Ginza. Times Square can't hold a match to this place (plus it is very clean!).This is my second time at the Courtyard Ginza. Highly recommend.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This was a really good stay for me. I used points for the courtyard and got a decent room. The room was actually more like a room at a nice marriott or renaissance. The staff was very nice, very helpful, and even made reservations for us for some restaurants we found in the michelin guide. The room was fairly large as was the bathroom. The hotel was very quiet. Location is really good for ginza shopping and some nearby restaurants & izakayas. There's a few coffee shops nearby both local and american which works out as the meal & drink prices at the hotel are astronomical. Both Ginza station and Higashi-Ginza station are within walking distance.I would stay here again and would recommend it.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The rooms are huge by Japanese standards. Beautifully appointed. Bathrooms are nice size, not huge. Bed is super comfortable Marriott luxury. Only one English TV channel (BBC) but big 42" flat screen TV. Mini bar, big closet, dresser, robe, etc...Window does not open but room is very quiet. However, Ginza is dead after 23:00.Location is good for Ginza. About an 8 minute walk from the Yurakucho JR station. Long walk (1 mile+) from Tokyo station, but I did it. Very hard to find if you are walking and not familiar with the address system of Tokyo, even though it is on a main street. There is a Denny's restaurant across the street for American style meals, if desired.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stayed at this hotel for a few days to do some site seeing in Tokyo. I am a Marriott platinum member, and did not feel it at this hotel- I was not given a room upgrade, there is no lounge, no free wireless etc. However, the rooms are quite modern- but small, but I guess that is to be expected. The location was really amazing- close to subways and the Ginza area is very nice. I wanted to point out how helpful the staff was in helping me plan site seeing. First off, they have these really helpful papers on all the tourist attractions in Tokyo and exactly how to get there from the hotel and what to do at each- I thought this was awesome. The front desk staff also spent around 15 minutes with me helping me plan my two days most efficiently. I would stay here again- it was a good hotel, no major complaints!
user_name:
lea5834
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Really good location for seeing Ginza and the Tsukiji Market. Excellent staff. Nice rooms...small but not too small. It's a Marriott, so you know it's going to be a decent place.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed here last week for work. The rooms are small but that is quite usual for Japan especially Tokyo. I have never been to Japan before but it was in a great location right near all the designer shops. There is an excellent tepanyaki restaurant next door called Ten. If you are taller than 5'9" I think you might struggle to stand up in the bathroom - check with the hotel as other rooms may have a higher ceiling in the bathroom. Only major negative was no wifi in the hotel but free Internet access if you have a laptop- no good if you want to check your phone or use you iPad

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Very small rooms, clean, very well located, good service

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: On a recent business trip to Japan my coworkers and I decided to stay overnight in Tokyo instead of taking the usual morning train to Narita. My coworkers picked the Courtyard because it seemed like it would be in a good location and he wound up picking a great location. The Courtyard is in the heart of the Ginza shopping district and a few blocks away from a lot of great shopping, window shopping and restaurants. The hotel is also about a 10 to 15 minute walks to the famous Tsukiji fish market. The fish market offers free admission to the Tuna auction. However the Auction is only open to the first 120 people and you have to get there before % am. We woke up early and got there about 15 minutes before 5 and it was already full but there is a whole market area outside of the fish market which has stalls with food stands, fresh fish, and ceramic plates, cups etc. This is where the locals go and you can get some good stuff there. It started opening around 5 am and by 6 am it was bustling with people. The hotel is also close the Tokyo subway system and Ginza station and if you are up for a nice walk the Imperial Palace is about a 30 minute walk away. The hotel itself was very nice a functional. The staff was very friendly and helpful. We asked about stuff to see and do and they quickly came up with suggestions and information. The one thing I always like about Japan as a whole is the friendly and attentive nature of the staff at hotels and restaurants, and the Courtyard staff was very good. Overall I would recommend this place for people visiting Tokyo and want to be in the heart of the city at a very reasonably priced hotel and I would stay there again.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The only good thing about this hotel is its location. Otherwise, this hotel was rather disappointing, especially having in mind the price which comes up to more than $350 per night web all taxes are included. Rooms are small. So it she bathroom. This is Tokyo , so it was to be expected, but still.... There is no free wireless internet. I always thought it was ironic that the cheaper the hotel is, the more amenities you have (such as free breakfast and free internet, and vice versa). Only free wireless is near the front desk and the connection was frequently lost. No pool either. Staff is helpful, but condescending. The most annoying thing is that for the first 3 days they only gave us one room key (3 of us in the room), and although we kept asking for a second key (which btw is just a card key that they will charge 1000 yen for if you lose it!!!), they kept telling us that they have no cards available to give us as a spare key. That meant that my whole family had to return to the hotel if one person wanted to take the afternoon nap, because of the key. The elevators also need a key to get to a correct floor, so either way, there is no free time to go explore Tokyo on your own, since your whole day revolves around coming back to the hotel at the same time to be able to get to your room. For a hotel that expensive, that is inexcusable. We only received the second key the last day of our stay, and were duly warned not to lose it because it is not only a rare commodity, but an expensive one to replace as well. Would not recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: dont bother to buy the breakfast coupon, its end up they open the breakfast at 6.30 not 6am, I wasted 8 breakfast coupon. dont lost your key, it cost 1000yen. the hotel didnt have air conditioned, all they have is heater and it was very warm, they give us fan, yes fan. over all its just ok. location is good. 100m for 24h convenience store, 2 blocks away from ginza. and few blocks from tsukiji.will I be back here? yes, for the location.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stayed on business in early February, 2012 for 4 days. The location is just up from the famous Ginza downtown shopping district. Although a ritzy and expensive area of Tokyo to be, the hotel offered good value and reputation. The area is very clean and safe to walk around even at night and many of the bars/cafe's stay open till very late. I recommend Bar 300 up the road in which all drinks are 300 yen all night which is a great value considering the area!The hotel rooms were very clean and spacious, (an exact size and quality of a Courtyard in the USA). The hotel was also close to the fishermen's market which I insist every tourist must see, especially if you like seafood as the sashime was minutes old!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: 1. Note for Japan hotels - it is very common for the hotels to have wireless internet access in the lobby area ONLY, and LAN connections in the rooms.2. Note for addresses in Tokyo - in general, especially in central Tokyo, addresses are very easy to identify: the first number is like the region within the neighborhood area, second number is like the section within the region, and third number is like the 'street number'. So for the Courtyard, 6-14-10 means it is in region 6 of Ginza, section 14, and number 10 of that section.3. Note for getting around in Tokyo - bulletin board of maps are all over the place, especially in tourist heavy areas (which is pretty much everywhere), with English and Japanese marks. The subway system is also very well marked - stations are indexed and lines are color coded, making it easy for travelers from any country.4. Note for services in general - Japanese are famous for their politeness and great manners. Expect great service everywhere, and most will never accept a tip.Hotel:Location - Ginza is already a very central neighborhood of Tokyo. The Courtyard is located in a super convenient spot in Ginza, but with relative quietness away from the 'central boulevard': 2 short blocks from the main street of Ginza, 2 blocks from Hiragashi-Ginza subway stop (East-Ginza), 3 blocks from the Ginza subway stop (a major hub of the Ginza (orange) line), 10min walk to the famous Tsukiji Fish Market (although the market will be moved to another area of Tokyo later in 2012), 15min walk to the beautiful Hama-Rikyu Garden, and convenient to many other major attractions. Restaurant varieties are plenty, and certainly with many big brand names and department stores for shopping nearby.Inside - beautiful lobby, bigger guest rooms compared to other Tokyo hotels and very tastefully decorated (bed, chaise, mini-frig, narrow table, safe, drawers, sliding door closet, good size bathroom) and very well maintained (clean and fresh), free business center (printing/copying cost 20yen/page), free storage of extra luggage you don't want to put inside the rooms. Courtyard also added a great touch to install universal electrical outlets in all guest rooms, in addition to the standard 2-flat-pronged outlets Japan has. Water pressure is superb - never had this strong of water pressure before (in a good way), from both the sink and the shower. Bed is very comfortable.Service - SUPERB. Key point-winners - always enough staff at the front desk for little waiting time, great maid service (e.g. neatly put away a half-glass of leftover water adding a cover), thinking ahead for the guests by extracting stored luggage well BEFORE we went down to the lobby early in the morning on check-out day, free umbrellas for guests (no sign-in/out required, just grab and go). Bell captains are very tentative and knowledgeable.Restaurant - expensive (e.g. $23 breakfast). Did not eat at the hotel so do not know how good the food is. Room service items are very limited.Value - we paid $313 (including taxes and fees) per night. There are many other hotels in the area cost $100 less, but with smaller guest rooms or less convenient locations. IMO the value is very good for this hotel.Others - local calls 10-20yen/min, free in-room LAN internet access if you are a Marriott rewards member (~$30/nt if you are not), lobby wifi is free for everyone, simple coffee/tea in the mornings, very quiet guest rooms and hallways.
user_name:
LoveCity
New York City, New York

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Nothing fancy about this place, but nothing horrible either. The service is what stands out the most; all of the employees were pleasant and helpful. I assume mostly business travelers stay here, not too many tourist. It worked as a good base camp for our outings throughout Tokyo. Good location. Free wireless in the lobby is a plus. Access the hotel from the Airport via The Limousine Bus. Tickets for the Limousine bus are about 3000 Yen. Limousine Bus is the bright orange kiosk- can’t miss it.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Easy to get to from haneda airport via train and fairly quick on bus to naritaClose to fish market and short train ride to many other tourist sites. We did get free internet in our rooms as well.Buffet dinner was very good

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: After reading the reviews here, I was very reluctant to stay at this hotel. I travel a lot and am a platinum member of Marriott rewards, and always hope to be treated a tint bit better becuase of that. I travel for business and have pretty simple needs. The reviews here seem to suggest that this property is a rougue member of Marriott, that the rooms are small, the staff not helpful, and the restaurants and facilities are marginal.My expereince was different. Staff was plesant and helpful. The Platinum status was recognized, if only a little. There were a few discount vouchers (10%) presented at check in, and a room change (to a queen) was accomodated without much hassle. The romm is, well, a typical Tokyo medium star hotel room. Pretty tiny and claustrophobic, but pretty new, fresh, and clean. The restaurants are wuite poor; a coffee shop on the ground floor which serves bad western food, and an overpriced Japanese restaurant on B1. But, there are plenty of nice local restaurants right outside. Yes, it's technically in Ginza, but 2-3 blocks away from the real Ginza. The fitness center was quite OK. Relatively sparten, but with pretty good equipment (Precor) and clean. The TV slelection was Japanese or BBC news. Yes, the BBC news is dubbed in Japanese, but a simple click on the bilingual button on the remote corrects that.I wish a lot of things for this hotel, and there are potentially several gripes. But in the context of middle range Tokyo hotels, it's pretty good. Staff was great. Food horrible. Location good enough. Fitness center good enough. Room, clean and fresh but tiny.Would I stay here again? 50/50. For another USD 75/night I could stay in a very nice hotel in Shinagawa (where my offices are). But, that's not Marriott, and I am fairly loyal to that brand. Can I find any big "faults" with this hotel. Honestly no, so long as one views it in the context of the same class of hotels in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The hotel is just 2 minutes walk to subway station that connects to everywhere.. 5 minutes walk to Ginza for shopping. 5 minutes walk to Shimbashi for reasonable priced restaurants and bars. Good service from all staffs. Clean rooms and decent price.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The position is very good, in the heart of Ginza, where all the shps and restaurants are.The hotel is not on the same level of the others of the same chain, even if the people are very nice and helpful.For business people: they don't have the lounge and also the breakfast (quite simple, nothing special) needs to be paid.Even having the gold card I got a room on the 5th floor facing the wall... very poor!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The Courtyard Marriott located in the Ginza district of Tokyo is a nice business hotel with convenient access to shopping and transportation. I stayed in this hotel on three separate trips in 2011 and I was very satisfied with each experience. This hotel is not loaded with all of the fancy frills of more expensive hotels but it is clean, safe, and functional. The hotel staff is very professional and the service is always excellent. All hotel staff understand and speak good English and they know how to serve the foreign traveler. The bedroom and bathroom are a smaller than most American hotels but they a bigger than many Japanese hotels. They have two good resturaunts located in the hotel and they also have a good exercise room. I find this hotel to be a step above most other Marriott Courtyard hotels. One of the only downsides I found with this hotel, is they only have a few English TV channels.
user_name:
Nate L
Salt Lake City, Utah

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: A very safe bet, quite great rooms, centrally located, and great service. Nothing unusual for Tokyo, but you no what you get from Marriott.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Generally nice hotel in Ginza district of Tokyo. Bearing in mind the location the hotel offers relatively good value for money...but cheap it isn't! Just don't expect a USA style bill at the end of your stay

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Just come back from Tokyo after staying at the Courtyard.Hotel is fine, great location in Ginza and easy access to the trains. I have used this hotel a dozen times and have nothing bad to say about it, in fact i quite like it. Good rooms, Gym's OK, but the bar prices are off the scale silly, buy hey its Japan. On this visit i returned as a Gold member to Marriott. On check in - no room upgrade, on asking - no free breakfast, On asking - no lounge for a beer, in fact the gold card at this hotel is utterly useless and if anything made me feel stupid for even asking.Eventually a manager appeared and said we are actually not a real Marriott, but just a franchise. so there, you live and learn. not every Marriott is a Marriott. I Estimated over three days though that if there had been a lounge with an hours free bar or something like the others my hotel bill would have been hundreds of dollars lower, so if you fany a cheap beer in Tokyo, best try another Marriott.Having said that , its still a good little hotel and i wil lcontinue to use it

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: When you are a in the top level of any program, airline or hotel, you feel obligated to travel on that airline and stay with your chosen hotel group wherever possible. This allows you to enjoy all the benfits of elite status, the downside is that you tend to stay within the program when there may be better options outside.That said, the Courtyard Ginza is in an excellent central location. A short taxi ride to business and tourist destinations, with plenty of restaurants within easy waling distance.The hotel is well run, the premium rooms are very nicely laid out and everything works well. One complaint is the TV service, plenty of channels but NONE in English. Even the BBC service although broadcast in English, there is a voiceover in Japanese, quite irritating. There is NO WiFi in the rooms. If you have only a tablet or iphone you are SOL and will have to sit in the lobby. Mr. B uses a small device that connects to the wired system and generates a WiFi hotspot that will happily run multiple devices and he never travels without it!The breakfast service is provided in a cafe off the hotel lobby, this is a rather dingy affair with mediocre food and high prices. My advice would be to go out to eat.The Narita Airport Limousine Bus service stops at the Courtyard, however it is the last hotel and takes between 90 mins and two hours.This hotel is a solid choice but don't expect anything else.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Located a stones throw from the bright lights of Ginza and close to Higashi-Ginza subway station, the hotel is easy to get to (both Airport buses will stop at this hotel). The hotel is also 10-15 minutes walk to the Fisk market area, Tsukiji.The staff are both friendly and efficient as you would expect in most places in Tokyo. The restaurant serves a buffet breakfast for ¥1800 with a voucher at check in (this is very good value compared to other hotel breakfasts in Tokyo - I paid ¥2300 at another comparable hotel for a small serving of bacon and eggs) but you can always go to Denny's (across the road) or a coffee shop (Starbucks and Tullys both close, Pront a bit further), to save money.The restaurant also has a good buffet dinner for ¥2400 (includes seafood if you get there early enough, roast beef and a chocolate fountain). There is also a good bar downstairs where you can smoke a cigar (got to bring your own) as the ventilation is very good for a basement bar and it has a good selection of single malt whiskys as well as guiness and asahi on top.The rooms are kind of pokey and their standard room has two twin beds which feel more like single beds. If sleeping on a single bed bothers you (yes voice of exerpience here) then make sure to request a queen bed room which run out fast (yes found that out the hard way too). The room is otherwise adequate but then Tokyo isnt the kind of place you want to spend lots of time in a hotel room if you can avoid it. The only other quirk was that the TV only had Japanese channels.Value was on the expensive side for a queen bed room (¥21000 approx) but comparable to other similar hotels for the standard room (¥16000 approx).Finally the business centre is great. Whilst unattended by staff, there are 3 Internet ready computers and a photocopier in a decent sized room.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Rooms were very nice and tasteful, although small (which i heard is typical of Tokyo Hotel rooms). Loved the location - 2 blocks away from the nearest metro station, near Mitsukoshi Dept. Store and mid-priced restaurants. No free internet in the room though. One has to go to the lobby to access free wi-fi which i find inconvenient specially if you just want to rest after a day's worth of walking/touring Tokyo. Nice big tv but doesn't have any channels in English, so useless for me. Very friendly/accommodating staff! Very helpful with directions and other information about sights we wanted to visit.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Why does staying in a chain hotel always have to be such a hit and miss... there are some great Marriott Hotels around the world, but this is definitely not one of it. Aside from the great location close to Ginza station and friendly staff, this hotel has precious little to offer. That the rooms are tiny is not surprising, given that it's Japan, but they are dark, with poky windows. Internet access in the room is via LAN cable only, so if you have more than one connected device you are out of luck (aside from being charged 1,500 yen of course). In the lobby area, wireless is only available around the check in desk and the lounge next to it. If you want to log on while having breakfast, again you're stranded. And talking about the breakfast: I don't think I have seen a worse breakfast in a hotel of similar rank anywhere. Poor quality, poor choice, and a charge of 1,200 yen AFTER a discount. I would recommend to go around the corner to Tully's Coffee to get something decent at a fraction of the cost. Same goes for the basement bar, which charges 1,100 yen for a half pint of Asahi... don't think I'll give this hotel another go.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We went to Tokyo for our honeymoon and upon arriving to our room, they had upscale water bottles and a small dessert welcoming us to Tokyo and congratulating us. The bathrooms were really nice with a bidet and de-fogging mirror. The service was good, and the breakfast was perfect for a money start in a city where you are not sure what kind of food you will find. The rooms were small, but what do you expect when you are in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stay at this hotel 2-3 times a year and always find the staff helpful. One advantage to using this hotel is that the bus from both airports stops right at the door, no need for expensive taxis from the train station.The Western dinner buffet is quite nice and the hotel is surrounded by excellent shopping and restaurants. If you like Western breakfasts, Dennys is right across the road and there is a Tullys coffee shop right next door. The hotel is walking distance from the Ginza subway station.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Located just a few blocks from the heart of the upscale shopping district in Ginza. Easy access to the subway, and walking distance from the Imperial Gardens. The hotel itself is clean, comfortable, and very pleasant. The service is courteous and professional, and everyone speaks English well enough to accommodate American travelers. The hotel restaurant is very expensive (especially the breakfast), but there is a Denny's across the street, a Tully's coffee-shop two doors away, a two very short blocks away, and two mini-markets (Lawson's, and Family Mart) at the corner. I would be very happy to stay at this hotel again.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I checked into the Courtyard Marriott Tokyo Ginza. Although in Ginza, it is just barely, and it is not in the better part. When I checked in, I was informed that they do not recognize any of the perks that come with being a Marriott Gold Rewards Member (they proactively told me this, so I'm assuming they have a lot of problems).Upon arriving in my room, I've seen larger airplane toilets than this bedroom. It seemed very trailer like. And speaking of toilets, when I checked it out, there was pubic hair all over the toilet.I went online and found a room at the The Peninsula Ginza for only $100 more per night than the Courtyard. I'd compare it to like riding in a new Rolls Royce to a dirty old city bus in Thailand--no comparison and well worth the $100/night. I went down to the front desk and told them I was not staying that I was leaving. I hopped into a taxi rode for 5 min and arrived in a different world.I have been Marriott Gold for multiple years, so I consider myself a very loyal Marriott customer. This Courtyard is terrible, don't let yourself get fooled into going there.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: i was surprised by a MARRIOTT WITHOUT WIFI in the room. only paid internet in the room, but you can always enjoy free wifi in the lobby, not too bad, just inconvenient.location is very good. less than 5-min walk to train station, and the train goes directly to both airports. also the hotel is situated in the heart of Ginza area, so it's very convenient to go shopping or go for a late night drink. everything is within 5-10 min walk.room is as small as any other tokyo hotel. forget about Marriott, just think about Tokyo, and then you'll feel much better. it's a very typical Tokyo business hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed one short night at the Courtyard Ginza and to be honest did not have high expectations. However I was pleasantly surprised. Nice greeting from Front Desk staff and a clean comfortable room, though small. Bathroom adequate, comfortable bed and a huge TV (though nothing much in English, and could not watch from the bed because it was at the wrong angle).Location great for shopping and transportation, and for those who want Western food on the cheap there is a Dennys opposite.I would return again.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I chose this hotel because of its location in Ginza. I wanted my hotel to be very near the commercial area of Ginza but not having to rip my pocket. Hotel room is small but clean and cozy. The location is 5 star, just a corner away from the shopping area. And 50 - 120 dollars cheaper than others which are just around or a few meters closer to the Ginza shopping area. Staffs are polite and professional. Lobby is not so big and typical with the hotels in Tokyo. Drinks in the lobby bar is quite expensive. But overall this hotel satisfied my budget and expectations.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed for a week. Very good location, just around the corner from Higashiginza metro station and within walking distance from many major sights and attractions. Rooms are functional and clean. Small in western standards but normal for Tokyo. Tiny shower with low ceiling. In room amenities and facilities are good. Breakfast is poor. The lobby and the hotel bar are small and not impressive. No Wifi in the rooms, only in the lobby. As a Marriott Elite member Internet was complimentary, but unused since both my phone and iPad require WiFi. it was quite a pain to go to the lobby each time I needed to use my iPad. Front desk staff was very professional. Not the best value in Ginza, definitely not in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: being a platinum meber and this htoel being in Japan- I expected a prompt courteous check in in the room I requested!Nope- how about the last room sir by the elevator with 2 singles and BTW it is smoking. After I expressed concern, they sent a girl ahead while I was checkiing in to 'spray' the room to rid it of the smokey smell- I am no fool.Walked away and also complained to Marriott USA with no feedback at all- stay with SPG if you are a frequent traveller as the Asian hotels recognize you and take care of you. plenty of better choices in Tokyo!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We were worried about spending too much time getting around the city and this worked out great. It is near the subway and Kabuki is only a few blocks away. Even though Ginza is a very expensive area we found really good inexpensive sushi nearby. The hotel room was small but the bathroom large by Japanese standards and included a full size tub. Everything was very clean and modern and the staff was friendly and helpful. They have all the maps and tourist info you could ever need in the lobby. There is a business center on the lower level with free internet, computers and printers.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel is really a Japanese Tobu chain hotel with Courtyard branding. It is a typical Japanese 3 star hotel, in the expensive Ginza area of the city, not far from Tokyo station and very close to all the high end retail designer shops.
