For this reason it cannot be faulted for location. The rooms are of good quality with fridge, kettle, paid internet etc. In winter and summer the heating and air conditioning will work fine. But in the shoulder seasons of Autumn and Spring Japanese hotels tender to struggle because their a/c systems are single cycle and hence they have to decide whether to to heat or cool but one doesn;t have a choice. The rooms do have small opening windows though. Pillows are manmade fibre, but feather and other options are available on request. The bathroom is very very tiny ( another norm in Tokyo). If you are tall your head will almost touch the ceiling when you take a shower. The usual assortment of toiletries is available.Breakfast is 2400JPY although can be discounted to 1800JPY at times. The breakfast is acceptable, but not memorable.If you have Marriott Elite status you will get free internet, and might be lucky and get upgraded if you ask, but this is probably the exception rather than the norm. There probably are better value hotels around the area, and there certainly are better values away from Ginza.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: First time in Japan and the people are amazing. Stayed for two weeks -- beautiful room and people.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The hotel was a good base for my last business trip to Tokyo - the front desk staff was professional and easily handled a snafu with my reservation when I checked in. The overall level of English proficiency was excelent and I never felt too lost.  The location is great - with service by Airport Limousine (the big orange busses) you are around 100 minutes from Narita. The hotel is in the Ginza so there is lot's to see and do. You are also only about a mile from the imperial pallace so there's a good route for running or site-seeing (a quick 10k loop around the palace moat and back to the hotel) The restaurants on site were fine, but there are so many good food choices close by you probably wont need to spend much time there. The rooms were clean and quiet, the beds were a little softer than the Japanese standard - not quite as soft as a US bed but very comfortable. Same day laundry must be in before 11 and doesn't come back until after 7:00 so plan ahead if you need something cleaned - there is no rush service. There is no pool and the basement workout room was clean, with lots of equipment but very warm - great for an easy workout but not a place to get a hard run in.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I reserved two standard connecting rooms and it was very small. The hotel is conveniently located near ginza. I suppose if you are out shopping or sightseeing most days then the room size should be fine.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed there the last 3 visits to Tokyo. The hotel is 3 blocks away from the main Ginza shopping street, all the luxury is a stone throw away - very pleasant strolling by Tiffany and Ferragamo boutiques. (Although this visit everything was a bit subdued because of energy savings past earthquake).The hotel is not luxurious, but very comfortable and very appropriate for a business traveler. Good beds, excellent showers, comfy cotton yucatas. Room service is so-so, the gym is very basic, internet is fast, and I still can't figure out how to turn on English TV channels - can only get them with loud voiceover in japanese. But overall - great value for the price, and why bother with room service when there are 24 hr restaurants next door??

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We had just one night at this hotel and the experience was excellent.Our stay was made by the very helpful and very friendly staff who were always offering or asking if they could be of assistance. The room was comfortable and clean with adequate space to both work and sleep and the bathroom was well stocked with all amenities including those “ small items” you may have forgotten.High Speed LAN interent was available in the room, free to certain levels of Marriott card members or for a fee of Yen 1300 for a 24 hour period. The charge is reasonable compared to some hotels.The breakfast buffet was of good quality although the selection was not as extensive as most. We felt this fact may be the result of low occupancy as we saw few other guests in our stay. It is certainly true that current travel to Japan and Tokyo has fallen dramatically. Three Ginza department stores we visited were not busy, Narita airport was relative empty when we left and our plane not only was smaller than scheduled but was also lightly loaded.The Hotel is very nice and reasonably priced and well worth using.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stayed here for more than one week. Was on business so the quietness and comfort were top notch. Being centrally located in the Ginza and then only 10 minutes walk from Hama-rikyu Garden, where I spent quiet time walking in the garden, sat by the Bay and looked at plum trees and a 300-year old pine tree. 10 minutes in the other direction was the business and shops of the Ginza. Little streets behind the hotel offered cafes and wonderful little spots, reasonablly priced for a quick and enjoyable dinner of udon or tempura after a long day. Nice that there was a Denny's across the street when I would wake up at 3am (the standard jetlag problem) and sit in the restaurant and read, have tea when sleeping wasn't happening. Nice buffet breakfast in the morning in thier restaurant and free computer access. I've been coming to Tokyo for years and this is my favorite. I just missed the earthquake by days and can only imagine that if I were in this hotel, I would feel safe and comfortable.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We were here for over a week and enjoyed our stay.Lobby and Hotel: Modern, clean lines, mono-chromatic -- no bubble gum colors here. Rooms: Clean and comfortable rooms (some Westerners would find our room to be too small). Mattress were comfortable as well. Bathroom was smallish (not a problem for us) and had a nice deep tub with plenty of hot water. Japanese-style toilet a plus. Housekeeping was diligent and thorough.Staff: Accommodating, professional, friendly and went above and beyond what was necessary. Our American airline (not American Airlines) lost our luggage on the first leg of our flight. The Japanese staff at the airport and the hotel staff practically bent backwards to locate/return our luggage to us and did it in less than 36 hours.Location: Close to subway lines, shopping, and the famous Tokyo Metropolitan Central Wholesale Market; AKA Tsukiji Market.Business Center: Free Internet use in quiet location. Gym: The bare minimum -- a couple of treadmills, an elliptical, weights and a few machines. Clean and quiet, during me stay; worked out nearly everyday and never saw another person there. Restaurant: I would recommend going out and trying the great food (even the cheap ramen stands are fabulous) all around you. Even the Denny's across the street has edible Japanese breakfast. Explore!Price: Seemed a little steep, but heck, it's Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I have stayed at this property many times. It is in the Ginza District which means it is great for shopping. There are good restaurants, too. The only downside is the lack of a quality lobby or Club/Concierge Lounge, which makes it more difficult to have business meetings.If you are visiting on holiday, I strongly recommend it. Wonderful breakfast buffet with Asian and Western food. Within walking to great shopping and the Tsukiji Fish Market.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The hotel has a good location in the ginza district. It is near all the famous brand shops, and within walking distance to the Palace. It is quiet, with good beds and clean. The area is on of the wealthy areas in town and very safe. I woud stay here again. Japanese food is different than fod anywhere else in the world but good, and people are very polite.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I stayed in the Ginza Courtyard Hotel for 2 nights, one on my way to Hawaii and the second one on my way back. The rooms were naturally pretty small, but very modern and nicely furnished. There is no swimming pool, but there is a business center with 3 computers for you to work on or browse the Web. The primary benefit of this hotel is its location. The hotel is located in a very quiet district known as the Ginza. The Tsukiji Fish Market and the Imperial Grounds are accessible by foot, the Tokyo Station is nearby, so it is easy to arrive on a cheap rapid train from Narita and then take a taxi for 1000 Yen to the hotel. The Ginza Metro station is nearby, accessible by foot, so you can easily reach such remote locations as the Sensoji Temple in Asakusa, or Shinjuku. Prices are moderate, but I would recommend this hotel to anyone who doesn't have the means to stay at the Peninsula.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: It's difficult to get excited about Japanese hotels. Because of high real estate prices, rooms tend to be small but the rates not-so small.The first good thing about the hotel is its location. It's a 30-minute early Saturday morning limo bus ride to the hotel from Haneda airport. We could not check in so we went to the Tsukiji fish market about a 15-minute slow walk across the road where we had the obligatory sashimi breakfast. There is also a Denny's across the road and a Tully's Coffee just up the street on the left. We had breakfast in those places as the buffet breakfast was not included in our rate. Curiously, along with the card key was a discount voucher for breakfast. I never used it.Crossing back to the hotel and another easy seven minutes or so, we come to the Ginza shopping belt. And because it was a weekend, the street was closed to motor traffic. It was an amazingly calm atmosphere that made you want to linger around.The hotel itself has a reasonably attractive lobby. The marble floor is well polished, there are dark wood furniture to sit or work on. But in Asia, the lobby is not particularly awe-inspiring because it is chopped up.While we had been out exploring Ginza, the staff had taken our luggage to our room. Service was very good and there is no expectation of tips, unlike, say the USA. The room was a bit tight for three of us. They had moved a chaise lounge to one side of our queen bed and added a roller bed on the other side. There was only one chair to be used for work.The bed was very clean and comfortable and had the high thread count Egyptian cotton material. The mini-bar was reasonably stocked but there was no complimentary coffee or tea, although there were drinking cups, sugar and a kettle.The other surprise was in the toilet where mysteriously, they gave us insufficient shampoo and shower gel.The final minor quibble is the lack of English programming for the TV: it was BBC or a movie channel. As tourists spending much of our time away from the room, these are just minor quibbles. But for someone coming for business, who has to stay in the room to work, these quibbles may be major. And I should add that internet was available via ethernet cable at Y1,000 for 24 hours. There is free broadband in the lobby--fine for tourists like us, but a major hassle for a businessperson.All in all, I would recommend this hotel if the price is competitive. I suspect that there are similar quality hotels around the area.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This was my second trip to Tokyo on business, yet my first stay at this particular hotel and for Tokyo prices, this Courtyard's a great deal. The hotel staff is friendly and accommodating. The rooms are clean and well appointed. The location of this hotel is just blocks away from the main shopping district of the Ginza. Access to public transportation couldn't be any easier. There are many cool bars and restaurants near the hotel and even a Denny's across the street (I couldn't imagine eating there with all the other authentic choices near-by) I do recommend booking a rate that includes breakfast. The buffet had a nice variety of Japanese and American breakfast dishes.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The location in Ginza is the main reason to stay at this hotel. It is also within walking distance of Tsukiji fish market. The room was average, service was good. My biggest problem was the airconditioning, the air just seemed and smelled not fresh. The rates was very reasonable.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Our family of 5 spent December 19-24 here. We had two rooms which were larger than we were expecting. First of all, when you walk in the lobby, it is all marble, glass, and chandeliers. You feel like you are in JW Marriott and not a Courtyard. The rooms are beautiful with very nice towels and bedding. The beds are the all-white linen ensemble, including the comforter cover, that gets changed everyday. The staff all speak English and are very helpful. The breakfast is a combination buffet of Japanese and American foods. The presentation of the food at the buffet is beautiful.On each bed there is a kimono and belt. On our last morning, all five of us put on the kimonos and took some pictures. Since it was before 7 am, there was no one we could ask to take our entire family's picture. So we got on the elevator and went down to the (fortunately empty) lobby with our camera. I think the front desk staff were surprised to see us coming down in these kimonos, but we asked them to take a photo of us. They were very good sports and took some photos of us. Our pictures turned out great. Even though our teenagers were embarrassed at the time, when we got home they were glad we had the photos.This is a great hotel, in a great location. We walked to the fish market everyday, where you will find the best and freshest sushi. We loved Tokyo and the people!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This was my 3rd stay at this property. All of the better hotels in Tokyo are very expensive and I find this property to be a better value than most with an exceptional location. 5 mins to Tokyo main train station and right in the Ginza district. Very good security program here as year room key only operates the elevator to your floor. People working here will do anything you need. Their english is good. Room is an the small side but you're in Tokyo. Overall a great value and comfortable place to stay in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: This hotel provides a decent stay. The rooms are large by Tokyo standards, but very small by other standards. The ceilings in the room were very low. The hotel seems overpriced which is a theme in Tokyo, so that comes with the territory, I suppose. The hotel is convenient to Ginza, where there are lots of restaurants and shops. Unfortunately, the hotel always smelled like cigarette smoke. Also, my parents were staying at the hotel but on another floor. However, the key cards and elevators only allow you to access your floor, so I couldn't walk down to their room. This meant that I had to call them to meet in the lobby, which was extremely inconvenient, but wouldn't bother anyone who is not accompanied by relatives/friends on other floors of the hotel. The hotel's dining options are a bit pricey, and one could find dining venues outside of the hotel. The hotel is quiet. The rooms were not very cozy, however.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We stayed here for five nights in October and were delighted with out stay. The hotel is modern (western style), staff are friendly and efficient. The location is perfect for exploring the Ginza area and because its near a metro stop it's easy to navigate your way all over Tokyo.The Lion is styled after a German pub with gorgeous tiles, mosaic motifs and Gothic ceilings. The atmosphere is buzzing with lots of groups having food and fun. It offers choices from beef, chicken, sausage, spaghetti, pizza and lots and lots of beer. Located two blocks to the right of the hotel side entrance.We had a wonderful meal at the Majaraja indian restaurant (New Melsa 7F, Ginza 5-7-10, Chuo-Ku). We are ranking this among some of the best Indian food we have ever had. Our host was Anil Mamgain and his attentive service ensured we had a fantastic dining experience. English menu available.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: My son and I stayed at the Marriott Ginza. Spotless, efficient,but a terrible restaurant. My son had stayed there in 2006 when it was the Renaissance , he confirmed that the restaurant was far better and not so expensive. Location is superb just around the corner from Higashi Ginza station. I would definately stay there again but avoid eating there.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Excellent location.Easy access to hotel from airport. Save hassle taking the train especially when you travel with children and with a lot of luggage.Walk to the fish market and have fresh sushi for breakfast. Great experience. All the department stores are within walking distance, you can shop till you drop.Room is small but acceptable. Normally small in Tokyo but clean.Free Internet in business centre.Hardly get free wi-fi in Tokyo.Will go again in January!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: OF course, Ritz, Four Seasons or JW Marriott is better. But this Courtyard hotel has everything you need for a business trip : very fast internet (though not wireless), clean spatious rooms, well equiped bathroom and very efficient check in/out. I was impressed. Also the location in the middle of Ginza is great. Always taxis available, close to the metro and in the middle of Ginza shopping.The hotel also offers an excellent buffet with fresh and delicious food. For a soft price. I can strongly recommend it. The gym is basic, but has some elementary equipment. At least it is free for hotel guests and this is not always the case in Tokyo.2 irritations :1. don't loose your roomkeycard, They charge 1000 Yen per lost card ! Big business !2. nice flatscreen in the room, though only Japanese language TV. I don't know how they do it, but even BBC world was dubbed in Japanese.Otherwise : basic, simple, good business hotel for a fair price. Recommended !

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We stayed at this hotel for two nights using our Marriott Rewards points. The hotel was perfectly located in the heart of Ginza and was a short stroll away from the Ginza station. When we arrived we were upgraded to a Premium Room as we were on our honeymoon. The room was located on the top floor and was ultra modern and scrupulously clean. The bed was huge and we had a sitting area, widescreen tv and a large bathroom. The staff on reception and the concierge were very helpful and courteous, helping us to plan our trip and find and book restaurants. We ate in the buffet breakfast which was good and available at a special rate for hotel guests. If I were to return to Tokyo I wouldn't hesitate to stay here again. There were lots of good restaurants and shops surrounding the area and it was close to many of the main tourist sites.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: My friend and I requested two twin beds and got a very nice room, that was clean and spacious. The bathroom was also very clean and roomy. The front desk personnel were nice enough but we didn't really need anything from them. The concierge was extremely helpful the morning of our checkout and helped us find ryokan accommodations in Hamamatsu. The only drawback to this hotel was no in-room internet. My friend brought her laptop and sat in the lobby to get a connection. They are in the business district and we were there mid-week, so it seemed a bit quiet. It was a short walk to the main drag.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The room was clean, the bed was comfortable but the bathroom was a bit small. There was no coffee maker or even instant coffee in the room, and instead the hotel offered complimentary coffee at the lobby in the morning. It was a bit inconvenient to go downstairs for coffee. I would suggest staying away from room service as the menu was very limited and very overpriced. The location of the hotel was excellent with many convenient stores, coffee shops, restaurants and shops within minute on foot. The staff members were helpful but not enthusiastic. I stayed there during Obon and laundry service was suspended. Although Obon is an important custom in Japan and a lot of people go back to their home town, I was still a bit surprised a big hotel would not be able to handle laundry service.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: From checking in, stay and location (near to Tsukiji Fish Market, 24hours Denny's Japanese plates, the department stores and on and on...), we really had a good stay in the hotel. Definitely stay here again!!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I was very pleased with the Courtyard hotel in the Ginza Tokyo area. The hotel is located just several blocks away from great shopping and dining.Very convenient with the both Narita and Haneda airport buses stoping in front of hotel. Also, there are several major subway and rail lines taking throughout the tokyo metro areas.Rooms are very clean and business center allows you to access to free internent terminals.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Our family of four stayed in two adjoining rooms on the premium floor (as a Marriott Gold Elite member) and were totally impressed by the quality of the furnishings, recently renovated. Hotel front desk and concierge were extremely helpful. Location is outstanding, in the heart of the Ginza district, a 10 minute walk to Tsukiji fish market, 5 minute walk to wide variety of top quality shopping and restaurants (including one of the best meals we have ever eaten -- at a shabu shabu place serving Kobe beef, on the street behind the hotel -- and an excellent yakitori/robatoyaki grilled restaurant a block down the street). Only downsides were that the fitness center was small and we could not get wireless internet in the room, just in the lobby.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed here at the start and end of our Japan trip. By far had the biggest rooms of any hotel we stayed in around Japan. Great location, the Airport Limo Bus stops right outside of the hotel, definitely recommend to use that as transport to get to the hotel.The staff are mostly friendly and provide good service. Only the front desk staff appeared slightly abrupt and distant. Hotel is a short walk to the several stations, so not too difficult to get around from the hotel, also Ginza is only a 10 min walk. We didn't use the restaurants at the hotel as there are so many cafes, convenience stores and restaurants in the surrounding streets.Overall, we had a great stay, and would highly recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: My family of 2 adults and 2 kids just completed a one week stay at the Courtyard Marriott Ginza earlier this month. This was our first visit to a Courtyard Hotel and we knew that the Courtyards were the lowest class of hotels in the Marriott group and hence we went with lower expectations. We got alot more than we expected.The Courtyard Marriott Ginza provides a high level of comfort and luxury and is really not too far quality-wise from the pure 5 star hotels. he difference is that the Courtyard provides an understated form of luxury as opposed to the over-the-top luxury of the post 5 star hotels. The hotel is simple, elegant and comfortable and it made us feel more at home compared to the big 5 stars.The room was just great - small by international standards but very generous by Japanese standards. We had 3 beds in the room. This was automatically given to us by the highly discerning check-in staff who noticed that we had 2 kids in tow and needed an extra bed.This was without any additional charge. The room had a very cosy ambiance about it. We loved the use of dark wood throughout (not sure if it was real wood but it sure looked real enough), which made the room look very elegant. The Marriott beds were, as usual, super comfortable. The bathroom was spotlessly clean and came with a large bathtub that was great for soaking. The only dissappointment was that the large flat-screen TV only had 2 English channels - BBC and a movie channel. More would have been better, especially a cartoon channel to keep the kids occupied.The Ginza location is another huge plus point. After seeing a few neighborhoods around Tokyo, I woiuld say Ginza is the best place to stay in. There are big shopping boulevanrds with lots of high-end shops, bright neon lights and big crowds but there are also lots of smaller streets that are quiet, clean and quaint. These are dotted with lots of small shops adn restaurants. Its very relaxing to walk around the streets of Ginza browsing or looking for a place to ear. Definitely one of the most relaxing places I've been to inside a big city.The transport connections are another strength of the hotel. The airport bus stops right in front of the hotel (take the bus from Stop No. 7 at Narita airport). There are 3 subway stations close by - Higashi Ginza is a 2 minute walk to the left as you exit the front door, Ginza station is 5 minutes away and the Shinbashi station is perhaps 10 minutes away. First timers travelling on the subway will have a hard time at first because all the instructions seem to be in Japanese.This hotel would be perfect if it had a pool for those hot summer days in Tokyo and could do with more English channels. On the other had it has a business center with free internet, which many big name hotels don't provide free of charge.The Courtyard Marriott Ginza is really exceptional and is among the very best city hotels I've come across because of its comfort and convenience. It is my only choice of hotel in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I originally reviewed this hotel in February 2009. On my third stay at this hotel (in June-July 2010), I managed to get an upgrade to the premium floor. These comments are about the premium rooms plus a few additions/changes to hotel policies.Premium rooms are on the 11th (top) floor. These rooms are approximately 30% larger than the standard guest rooms. Major differences are: 1) bathrooms are twice as large and they come with a Western-style commode (no electronics); 2) there's a wide hallway between the bathroom and the closet; 3) there's a very large WALK-IN closet with a motion-sensitive light; 4) larger flat-panel TV (but still not much to watch for non-Japanese guests); 5) TV is in a separate cabinet with fridge underneath, leaving room for a separate desk area. The furniture is the same overall quality as standard rooms (cheap-looking laminate). Overall, the premium floor rooms are large and comfortable enough for two people, with ample storage and desktop space.In response to earlier comments from April, the rooms DO have air conditioning, and the AC worked fine despite the scorching summer heat. It's just that the entire hotel switches between heating and air conditioning on a seasonal basis. It's quite possible that they don't switch the air conditioning system on until late spring.The Ginza Courtyard no longer offers free breakfast to Marriott Rewards Gold/Platinum Elite members. That's rather unfortunate. Instead, they hand out a discount breakfast coupon for either hotel restaurant (discount from 2,450 to 1,800 Yen). Unlike Marriott and Renaissance hotels, there are no free internet privileges for Elite members - it's still 1,000 Yen a night and a rather slow connection. Fortunately, there is still free wireless in the lobby area as long as you can stand the smoke ...... which brings me to my only complaint about this hotel. The hotel allows smoking in one corner of the lobby, near the gift shop. They also allow smoking in the basement bar. The smoke permeates the entire lobby area and wafts up the elevator shafts to all floors. I do understand Marriott's non-smoking policy is optional outside the US and Canada at this time, and I hope the Ginza Courtyard adopts it soon. The Marriott in Nagoya, for instance, does not allow smoking in their lobby.Finally, I was told that the rooms will undergo a renovation later this summer. Not sure when the renovation will begin and what it would encompass.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: My wife and I stayed at this hotel for a week in early April for a leisure trip to Tokyo. I found this hotel to be absolutely fantastic. The first thing you have to remember is that you are not in the U.S., so hotel rooms are always smaller and we expected this. Having said that, the room was well appointed and very clean. Take the airport limousine (it's really a bus) right to the front door for $30 US. We heard another couple took a taxi from the airport and it cost over $200 US. The airport limousine is always on time (of course) and very clean with good service from the staff.You’ll be very comfortable in this hotel; the neighborhood is very nice, there are several convenience stores within a block or two and the subway is a five minute walk. We found the subway easy to navigate and got us to all of the popular sightseeing spots without the use of a taxi once. There are also many restaurants in the neighborhood and the fish market is about a 15 minute walk from the hotel (get up early to see the tuna auction at 5AM!).The two complaints I have about this hotel are the TV and the air conditioning. I was there in cooler weather so only one night did it get warm in the room but I did notice there was no way to turn on the air conditioning and I have read other reviews of the hotel in warmer weather where guests definitely found the air conditioning to be an issue. The other issue was the TV (and this is a small issue). We definitely were not there to watch TV, we were out sightseeing all day and night, but when you're getting ready in the morning or dozing off at night and want something on in the background there is only one English speaking channel (BBC) which runs its stories on a loop. This got old very fast.Notwithstanding the air conditioning issues my complaints were very minor.Pros - Clean, Neat Hotel - Very close to subway - Nice neighborhood - Airport Limousine stops right out front (last stop) - More reasonably priced than other Tokyo hotelsCons - Air Conditioning (if true, wasn't there in hot weather) - Only one English TV channel

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: We stayed during 1-4th April at this hotel. The hotel is located in the good location where you could easily walk to the subway, tsukiji market (in walking distance), Ginza area. Quite disappointed with the hospitality of the staffs at the front office, which I got to remind them everything of the platinum member benefit. I used to impresss with the Japanese hospitality but not with the gentelmen staff fromthe front office. Breakfast is ok as I do not expect much from Courtyard, you can choose either Japanese set breakfast or the international buffet. The security staffs are nice and friendly. The room is small but clean. The most disappointed is with the air con which is not cold at all. We cannot sleep till after 1pm and it was the same every night. The air con will get cool after 1am.......oh well!It would be nicer if they fixed the air con temperatureCan I have the Japanese hospitality back please!!!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: It is Tokyo, so rooms are a bit small, that is my only semi-criticism. At this hotel you are a five minute walk from the Ginza, five minutes to two subway stations, and ten minutes from a really interesting nightlife district (slightly down scale but very reasonably priced). The in-house Japanese resto is fine; the western buffet is reasonably priced if that is what you want. Good but not opulent breakfast buffet with an egg station after 0730. Lots lots of restaurants in the area and they don't have to be expensive. Concierge staff taught me how to use the Metro for the weekend and I never looked back. I left something in my room and they mailed back home the next day! The Happy Hour drinks and nibbles in the lobby lounge were a very good buy. Direct coach service to and from Narita at reasonable price.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Overall a nice hotel but we were in Tokyo for sightseeing and this hotel was not the ideal location for that. Not the hotel's fault just an observation worth noting. It was good for people who like to shop and the tour buses all stop here. The metro was close as well. Breakfast buffet was great and the hotel bar was a cool spot to unwind at the end of the day. The staff were all very helpful and friendly. I just became a member not too long ago so I apologize for the late review but I did think it was worth noting my observations in case there are similar traveler's out there. I would recommend this hotel in the end, just not for what we were in Tokyo for.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: The location is nice, the hotel is also ok and the rooms are good enough but we are used to have even better from Marriott. It was disappointing to find out that this hotel has no lounge for premium guests and that you only have free internet access in the lobby. .

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Stayed here for 7 nites in March 2010. The room is not that spacious and the view from the room is minimal. I was put up on level 6. The location of the hotel is superb, it is walking distance to the Kabuki Theatre and the fish market (10-20min walk). As for the subway system you have two options, either GInza station or HishashiGinza which is just 10 mintutes away on foot. WIthin 5 mins you are also in the major shopping stores. Overall the hotel was good especially its location.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Completely agree with "thnarf" that the air conditioning in this hotel is completely inadequate, he had an open window we did not and nearly suffocated...really needs some attention!

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: Marriott Ginza Tobu Hotel has gone downhill. It used to be a Courtyard brand unofficially, and it was comfortable + the location is great in the middle of the Ginza district. They have now redecorated and formally rebranded, to their detriment I think. The room is ok, but the service is not as attentive as it used to be. In particular, the breakfast buffet was really bad. I will stay elsewhere next time.Maybe the Imperial? :-)

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: When I was in Tokyo last December I stayed at the Marriott Courtyard Tokyo Ginza and put a video together of the room. So if you'd like to *see* what the hotel and room look like, check it out here: http://yelloww.net/blog/2010/03/courtyard-by-marriott-tokyo-ginza-review/I booked a standard queen size room, and checked in to room 1008 on the 10th floor. I asked at the front desk about the possibility of an upgraded room and was told that all of the rooms on the executive floor were already booked. As a platinum member I chose the welcome gift, of “Orange Juice, Fruit, and Japanese cake.”The room itself was small by typical American standards, but huge by Tokyo standards . Some of the interesting touches included the two Japanese style robes on top of the bed, and a cool lighting control panel next to the bed that can be used to turn on and off all of the lights in the room. Many Japanese hotels still use metal “keys” for the room — the courtyard does one better, and has RFID key-cards that you simply touch to the door to unlock it.The room also had a medium size work desk, flat panel television, sofa/chair thing, and a mini-bar refrigerator. I found the room to be nice and quiet — very important for me!The bathroom, like most Japanese hotels, had a toilet with a Japanese bidet seat. The bathroom was well stocked with toiletries including toothbrushes, toothpaste, hair brushes, and two *individually wrapped* cotton swabs.The only real negative for the Courtyard is that the air conditioning and heat is either on or off for the whole hotel. When I was there in December, it was a pretty warm day, and the room was a bit too warm for my tastes — but no air conditioning was available because the hotel was seat for “heat” and not A/C. At least the window in room opened so I could get some fresh air that way.Getting from the Courtyard to the airport is a snap, as there is a Limousine bus that picks up in front of the Courtyard every hour bound for Narita. 3000 Yen, and well worth it! Location wise the Courtyard is a pretty central area in Ginza — just a few blocks from the Higashi-Ginza metro stop, and right across the street from an AM/PM and a Denny’s.Overall I highly recommend the Courtyard, it’s quiet, centrally located, and relatively inexpensive for an American chain hotel in Tokyo.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: A well appointed, clean hotel in the upscale area of Ginza. Not only is there world class shopping nearby but the area abounds with great restaurants and small intimate dining experiences. In addition, Tsukizi Fish market is only a 10 minute walk away. We took a 10 minute cab ride from Tokyo Station fresh off the Narita Express. Efficently checked in we found a room of standard to larger than standard (Tokyo) with HD television, comfortable mattress and an excellent bath. In addition to the fish market and the obligatory Sushi breakfast there are a couple other dont miss experiences in the area. For after work and social Tokyo at it's best head to the nearby Lion Beer hall. A 100 table hall from the 1800s with great German mosaics, awesome beer and great small dishes of food. A local hang out with a lot of fun iteraction. Also just a few blocks away is Bikkuri Zushi- one of my favorite Tokyo Sushi spots. Dont let the line at teh stairs dismay you- it moves pretty quickly and the food is worth it.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: I will try to be as brief as possible as I do not like writing lengthy review. I travel to Tokyo 8-10 times per year for business. Although I can stay anywhere I want, I do not select hotels that are more than $250.00 per night in Tokyo. I usually stay at Prince Park Tower or Akasaka. Since I am a 4th year Marriott Platinum member, I gave this hotel a try. I must tell you that I was not too impressed after paying $250+/night for almost a week. Especially during such a bad economy in Japan, US, etc.Platinum treatment – At the check in, they recognized my status properly and offered special amenities. It was very nicely done.Rooms and upgrades – Upgrade was not offered and I didn’t get to stay at the premium floor (11th). 4 straight year Platinum member should receive such upgrades but they didn’t offer one. I made my reservation 2 month before the trip therefore having no such availability would be an excuse to me.Standard size rooms (Tokyo standard) and was comfortable. Extremely small desk. No view where I stayed. Although it was located in busy Ginza district, it was quiet.Bathroom was acceptable but not great.Air conditioning – I were there in mid-January, during the day my room was too warm due to warmer than usual weather in Tokyo. Cold air was turned off and only had non-cooled air circulating in the building. When I pointed it out, the management offered a fan which helped little bit. If it was during the summer, it would not be acceptable.Exercise facility – Was acceptable and everything there was working.Service – Ok but not great for Japanese hotel standard.Internet - They charge you 1000 yen per 24hrs. Courtyard in US and other countries does not charge for Internet. I guess Japan is different. Transportation – Airport Limo Bus stops at the door. Last stop if you are coming from Narita. BTW, if you are a newbie traveling to Tokyo, DO NOT TAKE taxi from Narita to Tokyo. It will cost you US$300-$400 guaranteed. Airport Limo Bus is clean, comfortable and will only cost you 3000yen.Bell staff – Great! Promptly greeted me with smile. There was a young Japanese (and good English) speaking Indian native girl on the bell staff and she was just delightful in many ways. That’s the only great thing I remember about this hotel.Final bill – I was charged a different rate (WITHOUT explanation) than the reservation I made through Marriott.com.Next time, I am in Tokyo, I will most likely stay elsewhere. However, I would not mind going back to this hotel if they have a special rate around US$150/night. That would be the maximum amount I would pay for Courtyard Ginza.

hotel_name: Courtyard by Marriott Tokyo Ginza Hotel
review_body: It was my 2nd time at the hotel, encouraged by the no-frills but decent service I received previously and the prime Ginza location. On my return one night, I found my shopping bag left on the table gone. On initial clarification with the hotel, they were quite adamant that housekeeping would only throw away items placed beside the dustbin. They concluded after investigation that the housekeeping staff accidentally threw away my bag (& can no longer be found) together with the empty bottle beside. When I further wrote in to Marriot, they reminded me that I could use the hotel safe for storage of valuables. IMO, the item was by no means valuable as it only contained other shopping bags I intended to keep but it made me doubt the security of the hotel. Did the housekeeping staff peeped (at personal items) and concluded there was nothing "valuable" inside? What if I had not unpacked the stuff I bought? When I enquired about benefits for the Marriotts Gold program I was misinformed by the check-in staff there was no entitlement at a Courtyard hotel. I found out later that I would be entitled to a room upgrade if it had been available. And my preference for a double/ Kings bed was not given.
